src:
FOTO: Korupcija do neba: kar 24 milijonov za 25 avtomobilov
Zaseženi vozni park podpredsednika Ekvatorialne Gvineje je iztržil pravo premoženje. Rekord je dosegel lamborghini veneno roadster, ki lahko doseže 354 kilometrov na uro.
01 Nov 2019, 15:18 by E. B.



Prišli so navdušenci in bogatuni z vsega sveta. FOTOGRAFIJI: Reuters



REUTERSLamborghini je podrl rekord.


Kar 24 milijonov evrov je prineslo 25 avtomobilov, denar pa bo šel v dobrodelne namene, predvsem v domovini s korupcijo omadeževanega Teodorina Nguema Obianga.


Lamborghini je podrl rekord.REUTERS

Švica je leta 2016 proti podpresedniku afriške države uvedla preiskavo zaradi poneverb in pranja denarja; kazenski pregon so februarja letos po dogovoru s tožilstvom opustili, v zameno pa je Obiang odstopil vozila in plačal še milijonsko globo.
8milijonov je odštel anonimni kupec.
Razkošni avtomobili, med njimi ferrariji, maseratiji, bentleyji, aston martini in druga zveneča imena, so tako odromali na javno dražbo, ki jo je v Ženevi organizirala avkcijska hiša Bonhams. Premožni dražitelji so prišli z vsega sveta, največ jih je bilo iz Evrope, več vozil pa si je privoščil bogatun iz Dubaja, v čigar imenu se je za vroče blago potegoval posrednik.Največ je zaslužil lamborghini veneno roadster 2014, s komaj 325 prevoženimi kilometri, ki je iztržil kar osem milijonov; gre za enega najredkejših avtomobilov na svetu, doseže lahko 354 kilometrov na uro, anonimni kupec pa se je tako podpisal še pod rekordni znesek za lamborghinija. Obiang se je, kot kaže, tokrat izmazal, a kazni ga ne izučijo.
Da ne bi sedel, je odstopil vozni park.
Leta 2017 so ga zaradi umazanih poslov v Franciji obsodili na triletno pogojno kazen, lani pa se je znašel na udaru brazilskih oblasti, ki so pri pregledu njegove prtljage odkrili milijon evrov in ure v vrednosti 13 milijonov. Prav tako ne gre pričakovati, da bo sinu, ki je v svoji domovini znan predvsem kot razuzdani plejboj in zapravljivec, pristrigel krila njegov oče, predsednik Ekvatorialne Gvineje; ta je oblast v državi, ki se redno uvršča na sezname največjih kršiteljic človekovih pravic, prevzel 1979. z državnim udarom, od takrat pa skrbi, da si bajno bogastvo, ki ga prinašata nafta in zemeljski plin, deli le peščica ljudi, preostali pa životarijo.
text:
PHOTO: Corruption to the Sky: As Much as 24 Million for 25 Cars
The impounded fleet of Vice President of Equatorial Guinea has recovered real property. The record reached the lamborghini-worn roadster, which can reach 354 miles per hour.
01 Nov 2019, 15:18 by E. B.



Fans and rich people from all over the world came. PHOTOS: Reuters



REUTERSLamborghini broke the record.


As much as € 24 million has been donated to 25 cars, and the money will go to charity, mainly in the homeland with the corruption of disgraced Theodore Nguem Obiang.


Lamborghini broke the record.REUTERS

Switzerland launched an investigation into embezzlement and money laundering against the Vice President of the African country in 2016; The lawsuit was abandoned in February this year, following an agreement with the prosecution, and in return Obiang resigned the vehicles and paid a million fine.
8 million was deducted by an anonymous buyer.
Luxury cars, including ferraris, maserati, bentleys, aston martinis and other sounding names, made their way to a public auction organized by the Bonhams auction house in Geneva. Wealthy auctioneers came from all over the world, most from Europe, and several vehicles were afforded by a Dubai goddess, on behalf of whom a hot broker appealed for the hot goods. He earned the most from the 2014 Lamborghini driven roadster, with only 325 miles, who made as much as eight million; it is one of the rarest cars in the world, can reach 354 miles per hour, with an anonymous buyer signing a record low for a lamborghini. Obiang seems to have gotten a little messed up this time, but the punishments have not been learned.
To avoid sitting, he resigned his fleet.
In 2017, he was sentenced to three years of probation for dirty business in France. It is also not to be expected that the son, who is known primarily as a playful playboy and loser in his home country, will be fluttering his father, the president of Equatorial Guinea; that authority in the country, which regularly ranks on the list of the biggest human rights abusers, took a coup in 1979, and since then has taken care that the fabulous wealth of oil and natural gas is shared by only a handful of people, while the rest are alive. .
